Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Palatal approximant strengthening - social and phonetic aspects of a language change in progress

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Despite their seemingly innumerable differences, the languages of the world all share one thing in common: they continuously change over time. Sometimes these changes take an element of a language's structure in an unexpected direction. Such is the case in the language examined in this study, where palatal approximant sounds, a speech sound similar to the "y" in English words such as "you" or "yes", has begun to be pronounced as the affricate "j" in the English word "jeans" or the fricative "s" in the English word "closure". This change is known as palatal approximant strengthening because the affricate and fricative sounds replacing the approximant require more articulatory effort and produce more acoustic energy in the speech signal. Most phonetic changes result in sounds characterized by less articulatory effort and less acoustic energy, and, thus, palatal approximant strengthening is an unexpected change. Studying a cross-linguistically rare type of phonetic change like palatal approximant strengthening offers a chance to gain deeper empirical insight into the physiological, social and linguistic forces that conspire to shape how individuals communicate and how languages change over time.

This project is guided by three research questions that are of descriptive and theoretical importance to the field of sociophonetics and its various applications (e.g. natural language processing, forensic science, etc.): 1) What is the acoustic profile of palatal approximant strengthening in particular languages where it occurs? 2) What are the linguistic factors that condition palatal approximant strengthening in particular and phonetic strengthening more generally? and 3) How does palatal approximant strengthening pattern in the social matrix of speaker groups comprising the speech community for the relevant languages? To address these questions, this study's research design integrates a triangulated acoustic analysis of experimental and conversational speech data gathered from a large, diverse sample of speakers. The resulting corpus of speech data will be made available to the public through the Texas Data Repository for continued scholarly and industry-related use.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview and Intellectual Merit

Despite their seemingly innumerable differences, the languages of the world share one thing in common: they continuously change. Sometimes these changes take an element of a language’s structure in an unexpected direction. Such is the case in the variety of Spanish spoken in Medellín, Colombia, where an innovative form of pronunciation appears to have taken hold. In most varieties of Spanish, the letters “y” and “ll” are pronounced as a palatal approximant sound, similar to the “y” in the English words “you” or “yes”. In Medellín Spanish, these two letters have begun to be variably pronounced as affricate or fricative sounds, like the affricate “j” in the English “jeans” or the fricative “s” in the English “closure”. The phonetic process underlying these innovative forms of pronouncing “y” and “ll” is known as palatal approximant strengthening, as the affricate and fricative sounds presumed to be replacing the traditional approximant require more articulatory effort and produce more acoustic energy in the speech signal. Since phonetic variation and the sound changes it may occasion typically result in new forms of pronunciation characterized by less articulatory effort and less acoustic energy, palatal approximant strengthening can be considered an unexpected change (Bybee and Easterday, 2019). To date, little is known about the groups of speakers in Medellín who use the innovative, strengthened forms or the linguistic mechanisms that condition their use.

Taking these observations as a starting point, we carried out a sociophonetic analysis of palatal approximant strengthening in Medellín Spanish. The analysis was guided by two goals, one sociolinguistic and the other phonetic. The first goal was to examine the relationship between palatal approximant strengthening and several sociodemographic categories such as speaker gender, age and socioeconomic background to determine whether palatal approximant strengthening in Medellín Spanish is a phonetic change in progress or a case of stable sociolinguistic variation. The second goal was to identify the linguistic factors that constrain palatal approximant strengthening and based on these results, posit aerodynamic and articulatory mechanisms that conspire to increase the likelihood that strengthening will occur. We analyzed a corpus of conversational data gathered from 55 native speakers of Medellín Spanish to address these two broad questions. The results from the social side of our analysis did not provide evidence supporting the hypothesis that palatal approximant strengthening represents a phonetic change in progress in Medellín Spanish. However, our models did show a robust tendency on the part of female speakers to produce phonetically stronger tokens of the palatal approximant than male speakers. This suggests that palatal approximant strengthening is a socially conditioned—and perhaps socially significant—feature of this variety. Regarding the linguistic factors, the model results indicated that strengthening is more likely when the palatal occurs in a stressed syllable or before the high front vowel /i/. These findings point to a context-dependent confluence of aerodynamic and articulatory mechanisms including increases in the volume and velocity of airflow in the oral cavity, both of which contribute to the production of turbulence noise that defines approximant strengthening.

Broader Impact

A portion of the funds provided for this project were allotted to train two Hispanic undergraduate research assistants from the PI’s and Co-PI’s university in the transcription and processing of the conversational data. The resulting transcriptions will be made publicly available through the Texas Data Repository to promote further sociolinguistic research on this understudied variety of Spanish. In an effort to promote inter-institutional dialogue and collaboration, the Co-PI also presented the study’s findings and hosted sociophonetics workshops at the University of Antioquia in Medellín, Colombia. Finally, a Spanish-language audio summary of the findings and their import will be disseminated to the study’s participants following publication of the dissertation.
